docs.snippet: In this lesson, students learn about the competition between the United States and Venezuela for a closer alliance with Uruguay. They then search The New York Times for other examples of geopolitical alliances to discuss and research further.
docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

docs.snippet: IT seemed like a perfectly sensible plan at the time. Glynis Berry and Hideaki Ariizumi's popular little art gallery, Art Sites, in Greenport was too small to hold all the work they wanted to show, so the couple decided to move to bigger premises.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT seemed like a perfectly sensible plan at the time. Glynis Berry and Hideaki Ariizumi's popular little art gallery, Art Sites, in Greenport was too small to hold all the work they wanted to show, so the couple decided to move to bigger premises. Priced out of Greenpoint and Mattituck, they bought a beat-up cinder-block building, which had once housed a Jeep dealership, on two acres of land next to the Peconic River outside Riverhead. Being architects, they figured they would fix it up themselves.
docs.abstract: Architects Glynis Berry and Hideaki Ariizumi, owners of Art Sites art gallery, comment on renovation of new gallery outside Riverhead, NY, and opening of new exhibits; photo (M)

headline.main: Ugly Renovation Behind Them, Couple Eager to Show Works of Beauty

docs.snippet: The special section Broken Ground last Monday misidentified the birthplace of Rafael Viñoly, one of the architects who submitted designs for a master plan for the World Trade Center site. It is Uruguay, not Argentina.
